title: Grammar: Complex Sentences and Clauses

vocab.definition: A sentence with one independent clause and one or more dependent clauses
A group of words that can stand alone as a complete sentence
A group of words that cannot stand alone and needs an independent clause
Words like 'because,' 'when,' or 'if' that connect dependent clauses
A sentence with two or more independent clauses joined by a conjunction
A dependent clause that tells when, where, why, or how
A punctuation mark often used after an introductory dependent clause
Making one clause dependent on another to show the relationship between ideas

teachingNotes: Start with identifying simple vs. complex sentences. Practice using subordinating conjunctions. Show how clauses work together to create more sophisticated writing.

sample.question: What type of sentence has one independent clause and one dependent clause?
A group of words that can stand alone is an ________ clause.
A group of words that cannot stand alone is a ________ clause.
Which punctuation often separates clauses in a complex sentence?
If a dependent clause starts the sentence, a ________ follows it.
Which word can start a dependent clause?
Combine with a subordinator: 'I was tired.' 'I finished my work.'
expectedAny: Although I was tired, I finished my work
I finished my work although I was tired

sample.question: Which clause type can be moved around but keeps meaning?

truefalse.question: A dependent clause can stand alone as a complete sentence.
A complex sentence must have at least one dependent clause.
'Because it was late' is a complete sentence.
A comma is always required in any complex sentence.
An independent clause expresses a complete thought.
A complex sentence can have more than one dependent clause.
A compound sentence and a complex sentence are the same.

multiplechoice.question: Which word is a subordinating conjunction?
Which sentence is complex?
choices: He studied because he had a test.

multiplechoice.question: Where does the comma go: 'Because it rained we stayed inside'?
Which word can NOT be a subordinating conjunction?
Which pair forms a complex sentence?
Which best combines: 'It was cold.' 'We wore coats.'
choices: It was cold, we wore coats.
Because it was cold, we wore coats.
expectedAny: Because it was cold, we wore coats.

multiplechoice.question: Which shows correct comma use?
choices: Although he ran he was late.
Although he ran, he was late.
He was late, although he ran.
expectedAny: Although he ran, he was late.

multiplechoice.question: Which sentence includes two clauses?
choices: Because the sun rose, we woke up.
expectedAny: Because the sun rose, we woke up.

fillintheblank.question: An ________ clause can stand alone as a complete sentence.
When a dependent clause comes first, add a ________ after it.
A complex sentence has at least one ________ clause.
A group of words with a subject and predicate is a ________.
Two independent clauses joined by 'and' form a ________ sentence.
A clause that explains when or why is often an ________ clause.
A dependent clause needs an ________ clause to complete meaning.

shortanswer.question: Combine: 'It was raining.' 'We stayed inside.'
expectedAny: Because it was raining, we stayed inside
We stayed inside because it was raining
When it was raining, we stayed inside
Since it was raining, we stayed inside
Although it was raining, we stayed inside
Even though it was raining, we stayed inside

shortanswer.question: Give an independent clause about recess.
Give a dependent clause starting with 'when'.
Explain where a comma goes if the dependent clause comes first.
Combine: 'She finished.' 'She was hungry.' using 'although'.
expectedAny: Although she was hungry, she finished
She finished although she was hungry
Even though she was hungry, she finished

shortanswer.question: Write a complex sentence using 'because'.
expectedAny: Because it was cold, we stayed inside

shortanswer.question: Give a dependent clause that tells why.
Give a dependent clause that tells when.

expectedAny: cannot stand alone vs can stand alone
one cannot stand alone; one can
